column3: Boost Process was introduced in 1.64. Debian stretch has boost 1.62, other main distros have 1.65+, right?\n\nIf so, will we have any benefit of bumping boost version to 1.65 (instead of 1.64)?

> If so, will we have any benefit of bumping boost version to 1.65 (instead of 1.64)?\n\nThe only benefit might be being able to take advantage of any new Boost Test related features. However it doesn't look like there is anything substantial in that regard.

Tested ACK 957f3584277d33b44b9f1618142f743e4083eb5d that this fixes #22269.\nNo opinion on versions.
Please check at least RHEL next time. For reference, looks like it's got 1.66 so should be fine here.

> Please check at least RHEL next time. For reference, looks like it's got 1.66 so should be fine here.\n\nThis was somewhat covered by the fact that RHEL is based off a semi-recent Fedora. It would be fine in any case, because if it had a too-old version of Boost, anyone wanting to compile on that system can use depends.
